Description: Cast figure of the funerary god Osiris in copper alloy; depicted as mummiform and standing on small rectangular base; holding against his chest the sceptre Heka and the flail Nekhekh, one hand above the other; wearing the Atef crown, composed of the white crown flanked by two ostrich feathers, with uraeus on front and short horizontal ram horns (one broken); roughly made and with a very flat design; tang beneath base partly preserved; relatively well preserved though corroded and slightly chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The early excavations at Naukratis provided many bronze figures of Osiris. Some of them originated from a cache of bronzes found in a building located in the southern part of the city: it contained nineteen statuettes of Osiris, twelve of which were complete (Petrie 1886, 41-42). Osiris is by far the most represented deity in the corpus of bronze figures from Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). Bronzes representing Osiris, as well as the other members of the Osirian triad - Isis and Harpokrates, are conspicuous in Late Period and Ptolemaic bronze votive deposits all over Egypt (see for example the large caches from North Saqqara where members of the Osirian triad represent three quarter of the bronze figures: Emery 1970, 6). The Osirian cult is important in the saite nome, and particularly in Sais itself as stressed by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 445), but also on a more local scale (Masson 2015). This figure belongs to the type 86 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss, a type that is found in Late Period contexts, mainly in the Memphite region, but as well in Sais and Bubastis (Weiss 2012, 177-178, 649-656, Pl. 25a-h, Typ 86). The very flat and crude design featured on this figure is found on other Naukratite bronzes, such as: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.247, 86.251, 86.253, 86.261 and 86.284; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.616; BM 1885,1101.568 and BM 1885,1101.91.
